channel.title: Rock & Mineral of the Day
channel.description: Daily geology education featuring a different rock and mineral each day from Wikipedia

item.title: Obsidian & Gypsum - February 07, 2026
item.description:
ðŸª¨ Today's Rock: Obsidian

Volcanic glass formed from rapidly cooled lava. Sharp edges made it valuable for tools and weapons.

Learn more about Obsidian on Wikipedia

ðŸ’Ž Today's Mineral: Gypsum

A soft sulfate mineral used to make plaster of Paris and drywall. Can form large transparent crystals.

Learn more about Gypsum on Wikipedia

Visit the Rock & Mineral of the Day page for images and full Wikipedia articles.

item.title: Gneiss & Calcite - February 06, 2026
item.description:
ðŸª¨ Today's Rock: Gneiss

A high-grade metamorphic rock with alternating light and dark bands. Very hard and durable.

Learn more about Gneiss on Wikipedia

ðŸ’Ž Today's Mineral: Calcite

A carbonate mineral and the main component of limestone and marble. Reacts with dilute acid.

Learn more about Calcite on Wikipedia

Visit the Rock & Mineral of the Day page for images and full Wikipedia articles.

item.title: Schist & Feldspar - February 05, 2026
item.description:
ðŸª¨ Today's Rock: Schist

A medium-grade metamorphic rock with visible mineral grains aligned in parallel layers.

Learn more about Schist on Wikipedia

ðŸ’Ž Today's Mineral: Feldspar

The most abundant mineral group in Earth's crust, comprising about 60% of terrestrial rocks.

Learn more about Feldspar on Wikipedia

Visit the Rock & Mineral of the Day page for images and full Wikipedia articles.

item.title: Slate & Quartz - February 04, 2026
item.description:
ðŸª¨ Today's Rock: Slate

A fine-grained metamorphic rock that splits into thin sheets. Used for roofing and flooring.

Learn more about Slate on Wikipedia

ðŸ’Ž Today's Mineral: Quartz

One of the most abundant minerals in Earth's crust. Composed of silicon and oxygen, it's very hard and comes in many varieties.

Learn more about Quartz on Wikipedia

Visit the Rock & Mineral of the Day page for images and full Wikipedia articles.

item.title: Marble & Dolomite - February 03, 2026
item.description:
ðŸª¨ Today's Rock: Marble

A metamorphic rock formed from limestone under heat and pressure. Prized for sculpture and architecture.

Learn more about Marble on Wikipedia

ðŸ’Ž Today's Mineral: Dolomite

A carbonate mineral similar to limestone but contains magnesium. Used as a source of magnesia.

Learn more about Dolomite on Wikipedia

Visit the Rock & Mineral of the Day page for images and full Wikipedia articles.

item.title: Limestone & Epidote - February 02, 2026
item.description:
ðŸª¨ Today's Rock: Limestone

A sedimentary rock composed largely of calcite. Forms from marine organisms and chemical precipitation.

Learn more about Limestone on Wikipedia

ðŸ’Ž Today's Mineral: Epidote

A green calcium aluminum silicate mineral common in metamorphic rocks.

Learn more about Epidote on Wikipedia

Visit the Rock & Mineral of the Day page for images and full Wikipedia articles.

item.title: Sandstone & Chlorite - February 01, 2026
item.description:
ðŸª¨ Today's Rock: Sandstone

A sedimentary rock composed mainly of sand-sized mineral particles or rock fragments.

Learn more about Sandstone on Wikipedia

ðŸ’Ž Today's Mineral: Chlorite

A green sheet silicate mineral common in low-grade metamorphic rocks.

Learn more about Chlorite on Wikipedia

Visit the Rock & Mineral of the Day page for images and full Wikipedia articles.

item.title: Basalt & Amphibole - January 31, 2026
item.description:
ðŸª¨ Today's Rock: Basalt

A dark, fine-grained volcanic rock that makes up most of the ocean floor. Forms from rapidly cooled lava.

Learn more about Basalt on Wikipedia

ðŸ’Ž Today's Mineral: Amphibole

A group of dark silicate minerals important in igneous and metamorphic rocks.

Learn more about Amphibole on Wikipedia

Visit the Rock & Mineral of the Day page for images and full Wikipedia articles.

item.title: Granite & Zircon - January 30, 2026
item.description:
ðŸª¨ Today's Rock: Granite

A coarse-grained intrusive igneous rock composed mainly of quartz, feldspar, and mica. Widely used as a construction and decorative stone.

Learn more about Granite on Wikipedia

ðŸ’Ž Today's Mineral: Zircon

A zirconium silicate mineral used in geochronology and as a gemstone.

Learn more about Zircon on Wikipedia

Visit the Rock & Mineral of the Day page for images and full Wikipedia articles.

item.title: Migmatite & Tourmaline - January 29, 2026
item.description:
ðŸª¨ Today's Rock: Migmatite

A high-grade metamorphic rock showing both igneous and metamorphic characteristics.

Learn more about Migmatite on Wikipedia

ðŸ’Ž Today's Mineral: Tourmaline

A complex boron silicate mineral that comes in many colors. Often used as a gemstone.

Learn more about Tourmaline on Wikipedia

Visit the Rock & Mineral of the Day page for images and full Wikipedia articles.

item.title: Phyllite & Topaz - January 28, 2026
item.description:
ðŸª¨ Today's Rock: Phyllite

A metamorphic rock intermediate between slate and schist with a silky sheen.

Learn more about Phyllite on Wikipedia

ðŸ’Ž Today's Mineral: Topaz

A hard silicate mineral often used as a gemstone. Can be many colors.

Learn more about Topaz on Wikipedia

Visit the Rock & Mineral of the Day page for images and full Wikipedia articles.

item.title: Chert & Beryl - January 27, 2026
item.description:
ðŸª¨ Today's Rock: Chert

A hard, fine-grained sedimentary rock composed of microcrystalline quartz.

Learn more about Chert on Wikipedia

ðŸ’Ž Today's Mineral: Beryl

A beryllium silicate mineral. Gem varieties include emerald and aquamarine.

Learn more about Beryl on Wikipedia

Visit the Rock & Mineral of the Day page for images and full Wikipedia articles.

item.title: Dolomite rock & Corundum - January 26, 2026
item.description:
ðŸª¨ Today's Rock: Dolomite rock

A sedimentary carbonate rock composed primarily of the mineral dolomite.

Learn more about Dolomite rock on Wikipedia

ðŸ’Ž Today's Mineral: Corundum

The second hardest mineral after diamond. Includes ruby and sapphire varieties.

Learn more about Corundum on Wikipedia

Visit the Rock & Mineral of the Day page for images and full Wikipedia articles.

item.title: Lignite & Diamond - January 25, 2026
item.description:
ðŸª¨ Today's Rock: Lignite

A soft brownish coal showing traces of plant structure. The lowest grade of coal.

Learn more about Lignite on Wikipedia

ðŸ’Ž Today's Mineral: Diamond

The hardest natural substance. A form of carbon crystallized under extreme pressure and temperature.

Learn more about Diamond on Wikipedia

Visit the Rock & Mineral of the Day page for images and full Wikipedia articles.

item.title: Bituminous coal & Graphite - January 24, 2026
item.description:
ðŸª¨ Today's Rock: Bituminous coal

A relatively soft coal containing a tar-like substance called bitumen. The most abundant type of coal.

Learn more about Bituminous coal on Wikipedia

ðŸ’Ž Today's Mineral: Graphite

A soft form of carbon used in pencils and lubricants. The most stable form of carbon under standard conditions.

Learn more about Graphite on Wikipedia

Visit the Rock & Mineral of the Day page for images and full Wikipedia articles.

item.title: Anthracite & Barite - January 23, 2026
item.description:
ðŸª¨ Today's Rock: Anthracite

The highest grade of coal. Very hard and has the highest carbon content.

Learn more about Anthracite on Wikipedia

ðŸ’Ž Today's Mineral: Barite

A heavy sulfate mineral used in drilling mud and as a source of barium.

Learn more about Barite on Wikipedia

Visit the Rock & Mineral of the Day page for images and full Wikipedia articles.

item.title: Quartzite & Sphalerite - January 22, 2026
item.description:
ðŸª¨ Today's Rock: Quartzite

A hard metamorphic rock formed from sandstone. Very resistant to weathering.

Learn more about Quartzite on Wikipedia

ðŸ’Ž Today's Mineral: Sphalerite

The primary ore of zinc. Can be various colors but often brown or black.

Learn more about Sphalerite on Wikipedia

Visit the Rock & Mineral of the Day page for images and full Wikipedia articles.

item.title: Siltstone & Galena - January 21, 2026
item.description:
ðŸª¨ Today's Rock: Siltstone

A sedimentary rock composed mainly of silt-sized particles.

Learn more about Siltstone on Wikipedia

ðŸ’Ž Today's Mineral: Galena

The primary ore of lead. Forms cubic crystals with perfect cleavage.

Learn more about Galena on Wikipedia

Visit the Rock & Mineral of the Day page for images and full Wikipedia articles.

item.title: Mudstone & Chalcopyrite - January 20, 2026
item.description:
ðŸª¨ Today's Rock: Mudstone

A fine-grained sedimentary rock composed of clay and silt particles.

Learn more about Mudstone on Wikipedia

ðŸ’Ž Today's Mineral: Chalcopyrite

The most abundant copper ore mineral. Has a brass-yellow color.

Learn more about Chalcopyrite on Wikipedia

Visit the Rock & Mineral of the Day page for images and full Wikipedia articles.

item.title: Tuff & Kaolinite - January 19, 2026
item.description:
ðŸª¨ Today's Rock: Tuff

A rock formed from consolidated volcanic ash.

Learn more about Tuff on Wikipedia

ðŸ’Ž Today's Mineral: Kaolinite

A white clay mineral used in ceramics and paper manufacturing.

Learn more about Kaolinite on Wikipedia

Visit the Rock & Mineral of the Day page for images and full Wikipedia articles.

item.title: Dunite & Serpentine - January 18, 2026
item.description:
ðŸª¨ Today's Rock: Dunite

An ultramafic rock composed almost entirely of olivine.

Learn more about Dunite on Wikipedia

ðŸ’Ž Today's Mineral: Serpentine

A group of green minerals formed by alteration of olivine and pyroxene. Often used as decorative stone.

Learn more about Serpentine on Wikipedia

Visit the Rock & Mineral of the Day page for images and full Wikipedia articles.

item.title: Peridotite & Augite - January 17, 2026
item.description:
ðŸª¨ Today's Rock: Peridotite

A dense, coarse-grained igneous rock composed mainly of olivine and pyroxene.

Learn more about Peridotite on Wikipedia

ðŸ’Ž Today's Mineral: Augite

A black or dark green pyroxene mineral common in basalt and gabbro.

Learn more about Augite on Wikipedia

Visit the Rock & Mineral of the Day page for images and full Wikipedia articles.

item.title: Gabbro & Hornblende - January 16, 2026
item.description:
ðŸª¨ Today's Rock: Gabbro

A coarse-grained intrusive igneous rock, the plutonic equivalent of basalt.

Learn more about Gabbro on Wikipedia

ðŸ’Ž Today's Mineral: Hornblende

A dark amphibole mineral common in igneous and metamorphic rocks.

Learn more about Hornblende on Wikipedia

Visit the Rock & Mineral of the Day page for images and full Wikipedia articles.

item.title: Diorite & Plagioclase - January 15, 2026
item.description:
ðŸª¨ Today's Rock: Diorite

An intrusive igneous rock intermediate in composition between granite and gabbro.

Learn more about Diorite on Wikipedia

ðŸ’Ž Today's Mineral: Plagioclase

A series of sodium-calcium feldspar minerals. Very common in igneous rocks.

Learn more about Plagioclase on Wikipedia

Visit the Rock & Mineral of the Day page for images and full Wikipedia articles.

item.title: Breccia & Orthoclase - January 14, 2026
item.description:
ðŸª¨ Today's Rock: Breccia

Similar to conglomerate but composed of angular rock fragments cemented together.

Learn more about Breccia on Wikipedia

ðŸ’Ž Today's Mineral: Orthoclase

A common potassium feldspar mineral. An important component of granite.

Learn more about Orthoclase on Wikipedia

Visit the Rock & Mineral of the Day page for images and full Wikipedia articles.

item.title: Conglomerate & Apatite - January 13, 2026
item.description:
ðŸª¨ Today's Rock: Conglomerate

A sedimentary rock composed of rounded pebbles and cobbles cemented together.

Learn more about Conglomerate on Wikipedia

ðŸ’Ž Today's Mineral: Apatite

A group of phosphate minerals. The main component of tooth enamel and bones.

Learn more about Apatite on Wikipedia

Visit the Rock & Mineral of the Day page for images and full Wikipedia articles.

item.title: Shale & Fluorite - January 12, 2026
item.description:
ðŸª¨ Today's Rock: Shale

A fine-grained sedimentary rock formed from clay and silt. The most common sedimentary rock.

Learn more about Shale on Wikipedia

ðŸ’Ž Today's Mineral: Fluorite

A colorful halide mineral that fluoresces under UV light. Used in optics and metallurgy.

Learn more about Fluorite on Wikipedia

Visit the Rock & Mineral of the Day page for images and full Wikipedia articles.

item.title: Rhyolite & Talc - January 11, 2026
item.description:
ðŸª¨ Today's Rock: Rhyolite

A fine-grained volcanic rock with high silica content. The volcanic equivalent of granite.

Learn more about Rhyolite on Wikipedia

ðŸ’Ž Today's Mineral: Talc

The softest mineral (hardness 1 on Mohs scale). Used in cosmetics and as a lubricant.

Learn more about Talc on Wikipedia

Visit the Rock & Mineral of the Day page for images and full Wikipedia articles.

item.title: Andesite & Mica - January 10, 2026
item.description:
ðŸª¨ Today's Rock: Andesite

An intermediate volcanic rock named after the Andes Mountains where it's common.

Learn more about Andesite on Wikipedia

ðŸ’Ž Today's Mineral: Mica

A group of silicate minerals known for their perfect sheet-like cleavage and flexibility.

Learn more about Mica on Wikipedia

Visit the Rock & Mineral of the Day page for images and full Wikipedia articles.

item.title: Pumice & Olivine - January 09, 2026
item.description:
ðŸª¨ Today's Rock: Pumice

A vesicular volcanic rock so full of gas bubbles that it can float on water.

Learn more about Pumice on Wikipedia

ðŸ’Ž Today's Mineral: Olivine

A green silicate mineral common in Earth's mantle. The gem variety is called peridot.

Learn more about Olivine on Wikipedia

Visit the Rock & Mineral of the Day page for images and full Wikipedia articles.
